results.content: The course makes a large effort to make it very clear that you should have already done at least one django project before starting this course. Yet, after the first twenty or so videos, they still haven't covered anything that wasn't in the basic learn to use django tutorial provided by django. In addition, the introductions seem unnecessarily repetitive. Hopefully the material will become more interesting later in the course.

results.content:
I was looking for a "best practices" Django course meant for experienced programmers, not an introduction to programming using Django (which is what I assumed his other "try" courses were). I was taken aback by how poorly constructed the examples were, how off-the-cuff the lectures, and how un-pythonic the code.

If you have built large websites before using other languages or frameworks and are just looking to expand your skillset into Django this is probably not a good course for you. 

This course seems more suited for those who are looking to build their first web app and need some hand-holding and some direction. I do admit that at that—at explaining concepts to beginners—the instructor is pretty good. He answers a lot of basic questions that I am sure beginners will have.

And perhaps I am unduly critical and this course has helped a great many. But for me it was a waste of time. Examples were too basic and as I said not very pythonic. I was hoping for what the title promised: "a reference guide to core Django concepts"
results.content_html:
I was looking for a "best practices" Django course meant for experienced programmers, not an introduction to programming using Django (which is what I assumed his other "try" courses were). I was taken aback by how poorly constructed the examples were, how off-the-cuff the lectures, and how un-pythonic the code.

If you have built large websites before using other languages or frameworks and are just looking to expand your skillset into Django this is probably not a good course for you.

This course seems more suited for those who are looking to build their first web app and need some hand-holding and some direction. I do admit that at that—at explaining concepts to beginners—the instructor is pretty good. He answers a lot of basic questions that I am sure beginners will have.

And perhaps I am unduly critical and this course has helped a great many. But for me it was a waste of time. Examples were too basic and as I said not very pythonic. I was hoping for what the title promised: "a reference guide to core Django concepts"

results.content:
Most courses are project-based, which is one way to learn. 

I'm glad that an instructor finally took a top-down approach to teaching - explaining concepts from the top down, structurally, so you can start thinking more strategically about your code.

This is my preferred way to learn. 

And I think it's a mark of a skilled & knowledgeable teacher when they can explain concepts from the top down.

Thanks for creating a course like this.

results.content: Very useful course with a lot of content.   A little outdated but still, worth doing.  The course goes at a fast pace which for me is how I like it but I don't think it's for everyone.  If you want to learn Django, make sure you have some understanding before taking this course.  However, Justin does mention this from the outset.  I'm pretty sure I will be using this course as reference and be going back to it whenever I get stuck.  Justin is a great teacher and it was really great to see how even the experts make mistakes, but the takehome is how he debugs and gets to the solution.  This for me was very valuable.  Thanks Justin.
results.content_html: Very useful course with a lot of content. A little outdated but still, worth doing. The course goes at a fast pace which for me is how I like it but I don't think it's for everyone. If you want to learn Django, make sure you have some understanding before taking this course. However, Justin does mention this from the outset. I'm pretty sure I will be using this course as reference and be going back to it whenever I get stuck. Justin is a great teacher and it was really great to see how even the experts make mistakes, but the takehome is how he debugs and gets to the solution. This for me was very valuable. Thanks Justin.

results.content:
One of the worst courses I've ever passed. I've really suffered through it.

Pros:
1. Thorough in terms of the number of topics.
2. A lot of practice.

Cons:
1. If you aren't a professional developer (it look like the author isn't), the author will "teach" you a lot of bad practices: programming without an IDE and debugger, "navigating" the code base by googling, coding without style guides or even basic PEP8 conformance, using print() instead of logging and debugging, forgetting about security, ignoring basic OOP concepts, etc.
2. Extremely erratic. It looks like there isn't any script; often, the author would remember or try something on the fly. Sometimes he'd stuck trying...
3. Very outdated.
4. The author demonstrates poor knowledge of OOP, Python, Operating Systems, and Databases. He shadows top level and built-in variables, his method signatures don't match the parent ones, he capitalizes the names of local variables, forgets to call super(), etc.
5. The curriculum mostly matches the official documentation -- there's a little novelty.
6. Very poor coverage of ORM-related concepts: no advanced queries, no select_related/prefetch_related optimizations, no insights into Django Migrations and squashing techniques, no comparison of ORM-based features with plain DDL. For example, he doesn't mention that features like "unique_together=True" don't add any DDL-level constraints.
7. This isn't an advanced course that I've expected. I wouldn't call it intermediate too.
results.content_html:
One of the worst courses I've ever passed. I've really suffered through it.

Pros:
1. Thorough in terms of the number of topics.
2. A lot of practice.

Cons:
1. If you aren't a professional developer (it look like the author isn't), the author will "teach" you a lot of bad practices: programming without an IDE and debugger, "navigating" the code base by googling, coding without style guides or even basic PEP8 conformance, using print() instead of logging and debugging, forgetting about security, ignoring basic OOP concepts, etc.
2. Extremely erratic. It looks like there isn't any script; often, the author would remember or try something on the fly. Sometimes he'd stuck trying...
3. Very outdated.
4. The author demonstrates poor knowledge of OOP, Python, Operating Systems, and Databases. He shadows top level and built-in variables, his method signatures don't match the parent ones, he capitalizes the names of local variables, forgets to call super(), etc.
5. The curriculum mostly matches the official documentation -- there's a little novelty.
6. Very poor coverage of ORM-related concepts: no advanced queries, no select_related/prefetch_related optimizations, no insights into Django Migrations and squashing techniques, no comparison of ORM-based features with plain DDL. For example, he doesn't mention that features like "unique_together=True" don't add any DDL-level constraints.
7. This isn't an advanced course that I've expected. I wouldn't call it intermediate too.

results.content:
This course is great if you already know a bit of Django:

Justin explains well the different features of Django but does it perhaps a bit too quickly for someone who never touched Django. Sometimes, he may use some external code from his GitHub to illustrate his speech and thus, doesn't write it from scratch which could be a bit destabilizing for the beginners.

Otherwise, if you do already know how to use Django, Justin illustrates well how to use the more advanced concepts of this framework and his tone is captivating, so you learn easily about them. There's a lot of content on his GitHub to go into his explanations depth, which can also serve as "cheat sheet"

So this course is a YES for me, I recommend it for those who want to better know about Django.
results.content_html:

Otherwise, if you do already know how to use Django, Justin illustrates well how to use the more advanced concepts of this framework and his tone is captivating, so you learn easily about them. There's a lot of content on his GitHub to go into his explanations depth, which can also serve as "cheat sheet"

So this course is a YES for me, I recommend it for those who want to better know about Django.

results.content:
The course is good but:

1)	It is advertised as using “Python 3 and Django 1.10” which is not the case for all modules. 

This makes some lessons/modules/code lines to be incompatible with Python 3 and Django 1.10.

The instructor use video rehashes from other course and in some cases refused(at this moment) to update them   to be compatible.

Off course you can make the updates yourself (are not very hard) but I still think it is not ok.

2)	Some more medium-advanced topics are missing important lessons and details: like Foreign Keys, CBV with ModelForm, InlineFormsets, LoginRequiredMixin class, permissions and  PermissionMixin, recover/update/confirm passwords. etc 

The author recommends third-part packages to use, but still he should have talk about them.

3)	Many times he answers (not only to my question) with: “googling”, “search yourself”, “check documentation”, “ask on stack overflow” or vague.

From my experience with other instructors (non-Django courses) his answer quality is 4 of 10.

Regarding 2) and 3) my conclusion is that the instructor doesn’t know medium-advanced topics very well or he doesn’t want to allocate time to answer properly to questions.
results.content_html:

3) Many times he answers (not only to my question) with: “googling”, “search yourself”, “check documentation”, “ask on stack overflow” or vague.

results.content: Thank Justin, your course is very helpful and cover almost Django topic. I recommend to take this course to anyone who want to learn Django at beginning & inter level.
results.content_html: Thank Justin, your course is very helpful and cover almost Django topic. I recommend to take this course to anyone who want to learn Django at beginning & inter level.

results.content: I liked that it had a myriad of approaches that one could take for issues. In order for it to be useful, one would have to have experience though. But - this incorporates experience as well - which is **greatly** appreciated and not just fundamentals.
results.content_html: I liked that it had a myriad of approaches that one could take for issues. In order for it to be useful, one would have to have experience though. But - this incorporates experience as well - which is **greatly** appreciated and not just fundamentals.

results.content: This is a great course and reference guide AFTER you have done  a basic Django course or tutorial. Good for those planning their first own projects.  It goes deeper to details but still stays in simple and easy to understand level. Some cons however; I don't like the concept of first introducing the wrong or not recommended way of doing things and only after that the better way of doing things.
results.content_html: This is a great course and reference guide AFTER you have done a basic Django course or tutorial. Good for those planning their first own projects. It goes deeper to details but still stays in simple and easy to understand level. Some cons however; I don't like the concept of first introducing the wrong or not recommended way of doing things and only after that the better way of doing things.

results.content:
Finally I found a Django course that talks about the topics a programmer deal in a real-life project. It helped me a lot with projects and gave me a good understanding of the possibilities Django offers.

The only cons is that it is not a project-oriented course. If you do not have a Django project the course might not suit you.

The only cons is that it is not a project-oriented course. If you do not have a Django project the course might not suit you.

results.content:
Its good but need to think about following things:
1. Author is covering content in very speedy way; If it can be reduce then results will be much better.
2. Please avoid to use quick screen moving. It breaks the context.
3. Avoid to use copy/paste and instantly remove/comment the copied content. It creates mess during course learning and many logics become unclear.
4. Please switch the screen from left navigation controller. Not from top opened screens. It is creating a little bit confusion, from where screen is coming

Overall i have good experience because its increasing breadth knowledge and giving overview of things. It will help a lot when i will start real project.
results.content_html:

2. Please avoid to use quick screen moving. It breaks the context.
3. Avoid to use copy/paste and instantly remove/comment the copied content. It creates mess during course learning and many logics become unclear.
4. Please switch the screen from left navigation controller. Not from top opened screens. It is creating a little bit confusion, from where screen is coming

Overall i have good experience because its increasing breadth knowledge and giving overview of things. It will help a lot when i will start real project.

results.content: Great course. Must-have.

results.content:
It's a very comprehensive course, covers most of important areas of Django, a must have for every beginner to intermediate Django developer, advance Django developer may also find it useful as well. 

This course is not a project based, you will not build any complete small project at the end of any sections. This course is like a reference guide that explain certain Django topics with examples, then it is your responsibility to apply them to your project. 

If we compare it to an English class (not sure if it comparable.. hehe), this class teaches you grammar like verb, noun, present tense, passive void etc.. this class does not teach you how to compose a novel.

Definitely recommend for any beginner to intermediate Django developer.
results.content_html:
It's a very comprehensive course, covers most of important areas of Django, a must have for every beginner to intermediate Django developer, advance Django developer may also find it useful as well.

This course is not a project based, you will not build any complete small project at the end of any sections. This course is like a reference guide that explain certain Django topics with examples, then it is your responsibility to apply them to your project.

If we compare it to an English class (not sure if it comparable.. hehe), this class teaches you grammar like verb, noun, present tense, passive void etc.. this class does not teach you how to compose a novel.

Definitely recommend for any beginner to intermediate Django developer.

results.content: The concepts are explained in detail. This is more of an intermediate level course. That said, it's quite good for devs who are looking into getting a better understanding of the framework's inner workings.
